text: <ALL>Alu data for other European, Caucasus and North African populations were compiled from the literature for comparison purposes to assess the genetic relationships of the Basques in a broader geographic context.</ALL>
<ALL>Results of both MDS plot and AMOVA revealed spatial heterogeneity among these three population clusters clearly defined by geography.</ALL>
<ALL>On the contrary, no substantial genetic heterogeneity was found between the Basque samples, or between Basques and other Europeans (excluding Caucasus populations).</ALL>

<ALL>Moreover, the genetic information obtained from Alu data conflicts with hypotheses linking the origin of Basques with populations from North Africa (Berbers) or from the Caucasus region (Georgia).</ALL>

<ALL>In order to explain the reduced genetic heterogeneity detected by Alu insertions among Basque subpopulations, values of the Wright's F(ST )statistic were estimated for both Alu markers and a set of short tandem repeats (STRs) in terms of two geographical scales: (1) the Basque Country, (2) Europe (including Basques).</ALL>
<ALL>In the Basque area, estimates of Wahlund's effect for both genetic markers showed no statistical difference between Basque subpopulations.</ALL>
<ALL>However, when this analysis was performed on a European scale, F(ST) values were significantly higher for Alu insertions than for STR alleles.</ALL>

<ALL>From these results, we suggest that the spatial heterogeneity of the Basque gene pool identified in previous polymorphism studies is relatively recent and probably caused by a differential process of genetic admixture with non-Basque neighboring populations modulated by the effect of a linguistic barrier to random mating.</ALL>

text: <ALL>BACKGROUND: Afro-Caribbeans from Tobago are at high risk of developing prostate cancer.</ALL>

text: <ALL>We also examined the inhibitor of RNASEL (ABCE1) for variation associated with prostate cancer risk.</ALL>

Gene
Disease

text: <ALL>RESULTS:</ALL>

Variant

Disease

text: <ALL>We also observed a 20 bp insertion/deletion polymorphism 1,109 bp upstream of the initiation codon, but this variant was not associated with prostate cancer.</ALL>

text: <ALL>We identified 16 single nucleotide polymorphisms in the ABCE1 gene, only 3 of which had a minor allele frequency >5%.</ALL>

text: <ALL>A common A/G transition -1,071 bp from the transcriptional start site was genotyped and showed no evidence of association with prostate cancer.</ALL>

Disease

text: <ALL>CONCLUSIONS:</ALL>

<ALL>Our results suggest that common variation in the putative prostate cancer susceptibility gene, RNASEL, or its inhibitor does not contribute significantly to prostate cancer risk in this Afro-Caribbean population.</ALL>

text: <ALL>Alternative splicing at a NAGNAG acceptor site as a novel phenotype modifier.</ALL>
<ALL>Approximately 30% of alleles causing genetic disorders generate premature termination codons (PTCs), which are usually associated with severe phenotypes.</ALL>
<ALL>However, bypassing the deleterious stop codon can lead to a mild disease outcome.</ALL>
<ALL>Splicing at NAGNAG tandem splice sites has been reported to result in insertion or deletion (indel) of three nucleotides.</ALL>
<ALL>We identified such a mechanism as the origin of the mild to asymptomatic phenotype observed in cystic fibrosis patients homozygous for the E831X mutation (2623G>T) in the CFTR gene.</ALL>
label: Disease

text: <ALL>Analyses performed on nasal epithelial cell mRNA detected three distinct isoforms, a considerably more complex situation than expected for a single nucleotide substitution.</ALL>
<ALL>Structure-function studies and in silico analyses provided the first experimental evidence of an indel of a stop codon by alternative splicing at a NAGNAG acceptor site.</ALL>
<ALL>In addition to contributing to proteome plasticity, alternative splicing at a NAGNAG tandem site can thus remove a disease-causing UAG stop codon.</ALL>
<ALL>This molecular study reveals a naturally occurring mechanism where the effect of either modifier genes or epigenetic factors could be suspected.</ALL>
<ALL>This finding is of importance for genetic counseling as well as for deciding appropriate therapeutic strategies.</ALL>

label: Species
Chemical
Chemical
Species

text: <ALL>The mean protective effect by adding monoHER before DOX led to a significant 4.4-fold reduction (P<0.001, 95% CI 2.3-8.2) of abnormal cardiomyocytes.</ALL>
